title: Introduction to Sexualities, Relationships, and Families
description: This course introduces students to the study of sexualities, relationships, and families from an interdisciplinary perspective. Students will develop a greater awareness and understanding about healthy relationships that are inclusive of diversity. This course addresses relational violence.

title: Human Sexuality in Relationships
description: This course examines the development and experience of sexuality in a relational context from infancy to old age. Emphasis will be placed on sexual interaction and communication in adult relationships, but the effects of relationships on sexual experiences during infancy, childhood, adolescence, and old age may also be examined.
requirementsDescription: Prereq: SRF 204 or PSYCH 236; Level at least 2A

title: Independent Study in Sexualities, Relationships, and/or Families
description: Students will develop and write an in-depth study proposal and/or literature review based on empirical research and an extensive reading of a topic in the area of sexualities, relationships, and/or families. Students are generally expected to give a presentation on their project. The project must be approved by the academic supervisor of the course prior to enrolment.
requirementsDescription: Prereq: SRF 220 or equivalent courses; SRF 230 or equivalent courses; One of SRF 304, 305, 306, 307, 365, 366, PSYCH 354/354R; SRF 310; Level at least 3A

title: Introduction to Systemic Therapies and Anti-Oppressive Practices
description: In this course students are introduced to an overview of systemic theoretical and therapeutic practices in relational and sex therapy that apply social justice, anti-oppressive, and inclusionary practices. Students will consider and critically analyze the intersections of social locations such as class, culture, ability/disability, gender, and race within various social contexts. Student learning culminates in the design and presentation of an interactive exhibit project.
requirementsDescription: Prereq: SRF 101; one of SRF 204, 207, PSYCH 236; Level at least 2A

title: Introduction to Research Methods
description: This course provides an interdisciplinary overview of the philosophical, theoretical, and practical foundations of research methods used in the social sciences and humanities to study sexualities, relationships, and families. Students will learn about both qualitative and quantitative methods, the role of theory in research, and ethical issues pertaining to research. Students will acquire foundational skills for constructing research proposals and becoming critical consumers of research.
requirementsDescription: Prereq: One of SRF 101, SRF 204, PSYCH 236. Antireq: KIN 330, PSCI 315, PSYCH 291, REC 270, SDS/SWREN 251R, SOC/LS 221

title: Communication and Counselling Skills
description: This course introduces students to the theories and methods of communication as applied to processes of individual, relational, and family consultation and counselling. Through functional experiential activities and written reflections, students will apply course concepts and examine their own thoughts, beliefs, and positionings as they develop and strengthen their communication skills. Through application-based course assignments, students will deepen their understanding of intersectional, anti-oppressive frameworks and apply them to active listening and intentional interviewing across human service contexts and relationships.
requirementsDescription: Prereq: One of SRF 101, 204, PSYCH 236; Level at least 2A. Antireq: SOCWK/SWREN 220R

title: Thesis - Part 1
description: Under supervision of a faculty member, students normally will review literature, design a study, present a research proposal, analyze data, write a scholarly research paper, and deliver an oral presentation based on the paper (e.g., at the SRF Research Symposium).
requirementsDescription: Prereq: SRF 220 or an equivalent course; SRF 230 or an equivalent course; Honours Sexuality, Relationships, and Family Studies students with a major average of at least 75%

title: Practicum and Professional Ethics
description: In this course students undertake an unpaid apprenticeship in a human services setting. This practicum field placement is complemented by regular seminar meetings to support and assess student learning. The practicum field placement requires 15 hours per week for eight months (fall and winter terms). Through the practicum experience students learn to integrate and apply their undergraduate Sexualities, Relationships, and Families education and bridge theory, research, and praxis.
requirementsDescription: Prereq: Level at least 4A; Honours Sexualities, Relationships and Families students with a major average of at least 73%
